Java.Util.Concurrent
interface Executor



All Known Subtypes: 

ExecutorImpl







interface Executor

An object that executes submitted null tasks. 
This
interface provides a way of decoupling task submission from the
mechanics of how each task will be run, including details of thread
use, scheduling, etc.  An Executor is normally used
instead of explicitly creating threads. For example, rather than
invoking new for each
of a set of tasks, you might use:


Executor executor = anExecutor;
executor.execute(new RunnableTask1());
executor.execute(new RunnableTask2());
...



However, the Executor interface does not strictly
require that execution be asynchronous. In the simplest case, an
executor can run the submitted task immediately in the caller's
thread:

 
 class
}}


More typically, tasks are executed in some thread other
than the caller's thread.  The executor below spawns a new thread
for each task.

 
 class
}}


Many Executor implementations impose some sort of
limitation on how and when tasks are scheduled.  The executor below
serializes the submission of tasks to a second executor,
illustrating a composite executor.

 
 class

  public synchronized void execute(final Runnable r) {
    tasks.offer(new Runnable() {
      public void run() {
        try {
          r.run();
        } finally {
          scheduleNext();
        }
      }
    });
    if (active == null) {
      scheduleNext();
    }
  }

  protected synchronized void scheduleNext() {
    if ((active = tasks.poll()) != null) {
      executor.execute(active);
    }
  }
}}


The Executor implementations provided in this package
implement null, which is a more extensive
interface.  The  class provides an
extensible thread pool implementation. The  class
provides convenient factory methods for these Executors.


Memory consistency effects: Actions in a thread prior to
submitting a Runnable object to an Executor
happen-before
its execution begins, perhaps in another thread.







Since: 
1.5
